frameDefinitions: A Cognizer thinks of and performs an Action that is a self- or other-imposed task or some other kind of desirable behavior.
A Performer has a certain Role in a Performance and plays their part by following the directions in the Script for that particular Role.
A Speaker communicates a message stating an Item's membership in a Category, i.e., asserts that the Item has the defining characteristics of the Category.
Two or more distinct entities, which may be concrete or abstract objects or types, are characterized as being similar to each other.
An Agent occupies a Role in some institution.
An Entity is designed for or exists to perform an Activity or fulfill a Role. '' 'This platform will serve as a great stage for tomorrow's play.'
frameExamples: You invited everybody but you <t>forgot</t> Harry.
Margaret Thatcher <t>played</t> Juliet in a school play.
He <t>depicted</t> his involvement as merely peripheral.

A mulberry is very <t>similar</t> in shape
to a loganberry
Chris <t>served</t> as chairman of the boardfor one year.
This platform will <t>serve</t> as a great stage for tomorrow's play.
listRoleDefinitions: The person who thinks of or fails to think of an obligatory or desireable <fen>Action</fen>.
An <fen>Action</fen> that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is supposed to carry out. This may be a Task imposed specifically on the <fen>Cognizer</fen> or it may be self- or socially imposed.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> is a person or thing that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> needs to affect or effect when carrying out the <fen>Action</fen>.
A <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> remembers or fails to carry out an <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Audience</fen> experiences the <fen>Performance</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Performer</fen> to transmit the <fen>Performance</fen> to the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Performer</fen>s generates the <fen>Performance</fen> which  the <fen>Audience</fen> perceives.
The <fen>Performer</fen> provides an experience for the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The music which may be performed in the <fen>Performance</fen>, either in isolation or accompanying actions and speech.

The (usually written) directions which instruct the <fen>Performer</fen>s on what actions to perform, when, and how.  It has many different names depending on the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen> including <ment>script</ment>, <ment>screenplay</ment>, <ment>libretto</ment>, <ment>book</ment>, and <ment>choreography</ment>.
This role indicates the subtype of <fen>Performance</fen>, including <ment>dance</ment>, <ment>theater</ment>, <ment>film</ment>, etc.

<fen>Role</fen> identifies one of the possible relations that the <fen>Performer</fen> can have to the <fen>Performance</fen>.  The <fen>Role</fen> (s) a <fen>Performer</fen> has in the <fen>Performance</fen> will determine which parts of the <fen>Script</fen> should be performed by the <fen>Performer</fen>, as the <fen>Script</fen> is written in terms of which <fen>Role</fen> (s) each set of instructions applies to.  In the fields of theater, movies, ballet, and opera, a <fen>Role</fen> generally corresponds to a character in the story of the <fen>Script</fen>, while other types of performance may use more general <fen>Role</fen>s like <ment>lead violinist</ment>.
The person that performs alongside Performer2.
The person that is also in the Performance, alongside Performer1.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> an event occurs.
The individual that communicates the message concerning the <fen>Category</fen> of an <fen>Item</fen>.
The class of entities with characteristics that match those of the <fen>Item</fen> according to the portrayal of the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The entity that the <fen>Speaker</fen> portrays as belonging to a <fen>Category</fen>.
The piece of text in which a <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates their categorization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes a characterization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> characterizes the <fen>Item</fen>
This role marks constituents that express the set of objects or types whose similarity is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the entity characterized by its similarity to <fen>Entity_2</fen>, whose characteristics are assumed to be known.  <fen>Entity_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Entities</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Entity_2</fen> is the one whose characteristics are assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing characteristics of <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
This role marks constituents which express a property in respect to which the similarity of the entities is assessed.
A fact about <fen>Entity_1</fen> or the <fen>Entities</fen> that reveals how <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the same or different from other entities.  (Note the contrast with 'as to'.)
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the similarity occurs or exists.
The Place is the general area in which similarity occurs or exists
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the entity that occpuies the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Role</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> occupies.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Entity</fen> is an object or person that performs the <fen>Activity</fen> or fulfills the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Activity</fen> is the action that the <fen>Entity</fen> performs.
The <fen>Role</fen> is  the position or duty that is occupied by the <fen>Entity</fen>.
listRoleExamples: .<fex>Alex and Zach Swindle</fex>, Centre, visited their brother in San Francisco in June and remembered to take along a copy of The Post>.
This time we remembered <fex>to turn the gas off before leaving</fex>.
We piled into the taxi and right when we were about to leave, I realized we forgot <fex>the video camera</fex>
He remembered <fex>afterwards</fex> to kiss her fingers.
He co-starred <fex>with Matt Perry</fex> in Tool 3.
Who co-starred <fex>with Glen Close</fex> in that space opera thingy?
However, <fex>'A Brief History of Medicine'</fex> characterizes influenza as the most deadly plague, overall.
<fex>The two painters</fex> were alike in being unable to draw acceptably .
In the first phase <fex>Barthes's approach</fex> has similarities to that of Levi-Strauss.
The results of Method 2 show remarkable similarity <fex>to those obtained by Method 1</fex>
The disc announced Friday is <fex>physically</fex> similar to current music CDs
His presidency was different <fex>in that it offered a way forward for the common man</fex> .
